fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of Mr. Wignall, watercolour on vellum by Susannah-Penelope Rosse, ca.1690.

fields.name: Artists of the Tudor Court: the portrait miniature rediscovered, 1520-1620
Special Exhibition of Works of Art at the South Kensington Museum

fields.physical_description: Portrait of a man, half-length, turned to left, looking to front and wearing a neckcloth and long wig; oval on a rectangular sheet.  Features freely hatched in brown and sanguine, with grey-blue shadowing, black for the eyes and touches of white, on a pale carnation ground; hair in washes of grey gouache and brown heightened with ochre; cravat in white shaded with grey and brown; robe in brown wash, modelled with darker colour and with the lights in ochre; background a solid dark brown wash; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book.
fields.dimensions: Height: 93 mm sheet, Width: 69 mm sheet
fields.title: Mr Wignall, Painter
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book

fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the Collection of the Victoria & Albert Museum, London: The Stationery Office in association with the Victoria & Albert Museum, 1997. Cat.144, p.246. Full Citation: “144 Mr Wignall, Painter c.1690 453-1892 Rectangular about 93 x 69 mm with a drawn oval 78 x 65 mm Features freely hatched in brown and sanguine, with grey-blue shadowing, black for the eyes and touches of white, on a pale carnation ground; hair in washes of grey gouache and brown heightened with ochre; cravat in white shaded with grey and brown; robe in brown wash, modelled with darker colour and with the lights in ochre; background a solid dark brown wash; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Craquelure over the whole surface with some flaking and blackened whites. (1) Signed: Not signed. Inscribed in graphite, on the back: Mr.Wignal Painter (originally Mrs. was written but the s was deleted). Frame: From The Pocket Book, see Cat. No. 87. [460-1892] Provenance: As for Cat. No. 88. [Presumably acquired from Cooper's estate by the Rosses, or perhaps by Priestman (see Rosse, Cat. No. 143) and perhaps in the Michael Rosse sale, 2 April 1723; eventually purchased by Edwin [Durning] Lawrence before 1862, and sold by him to the Museum for £525 in 1892.] Exhibited: As for Cat. No. 88 [South Kensington 1862, no. 2531 (the set as Cooper); BFAC 1889, p. 133, case XLI, nos 1-15 (Cooper); V&A 1983, unnumbered]; specifically, Los Angeles and Nottingham 1976-7, no. 38. Literature: As for Cat. No. 88 for general references [Williamson 1904, vol. I, pp. 51-2 (on the set, reproducing four by Rosse); Foster 1898, p. 40; Foster 1903, vol. I, p. 53 (tentatively attributing the set to Flatman); Foster 1908, p. 184 (as attributed to Cooper, but Foster would give some to Dixon; he now states that some give the poorer ones to Flatman); Catalogue of Miniatures , 1908, pp. 9-10 (as formerly attributed to Cooper); Goulding 1914-15, p. 49 (as Rosse); Long 1929, p. 377 (Rosse); Long 1930, pp. 65-6 (as by Rosse); Reynolds 1952, pp. 81-2 (Rosse); Foskett 1963, pp. 77-8; Foskett 1972, vol I, p. 481 (Rosse); Foskett 1974, p. 91 (Rosse); Reynolds 1975, specifically p. 9, no. 1, pl. 13; Foskett 1979, pp. 125-6 (following Reynolds 1975); Summary Catalogue , 1981, p. 9 (Cooper); V J Murrell, 'The Craft of the Miniaturist' , Murdoch 1981, p. 12, fig. 14 (as Cooper); V J Murrell, 'Technique and Practice', Strong 1983, p. 28, no. 1; Reynolds 1988, p. 78 and specifically pp. 59 and 78]; specifically, Williamson 1904, vol. I, repra. pI. xxvii, no. 4; Reynolds 1975, no. 10, pl. 24. The 'MrWignal' identified in the inscription, has proved elusive. Long worked on his identity, and corresponded with Collins Baker, who wrote to him, 11 December 1910, with a photograph of a portrait identified as Matthew Gibbon, apparently signed Robt. Wignall. (Christie's, sometime in 1909). Collins Baker's letter in the departmental files has provided the basis for subsequent references to this miniature as a portrait of Robert Wignal. The only other fruit of Long's research was a note in the London Gazette of 5 April 1697 to the effect that one Matthew Lock (perhaps an early reference to Matthias Lock (fl.1740-70), the designer) 'went away from his master Mr. Wiggnall "picture-drawer'". More recently Mary Edmond has combed the likely archives for references to Robert Wignal and has found only one man of that name. (The surname Wignal, in its many variant spellings is itself uncommon, but Richard, John and Edward Wignals of the right sort of date occur in various professions and levels of society in Essex, Suffolk, Surrey and, of course, London). He was Mr Robert Wignall, who married Anne Sands at Knightsbridge Chapel on 9 July 1678; there is no indication of his profession. The most frequent archival references, however, are to a James Wignall, painter, of the parish of St Martin-in - the- Fields. This is the right part of London for a painter to live, and as close to the Rosses as other sitters for The Pocket Book group. Wignall's commercial connections with developments of the St James's, Piccadilly, Soho Square and Leicester Square areas of London, with Richard Frith (who left his name on Frith Street) and with William Pyrn place him as a likely acquaintance of the moneyed Rosse circle in the parish of St Martin's. Mary Edmond considers that, from the contexts of these references, it is clear that James Wignall was a painter-decorator rather than an easel painter. The inscription on the miniature, referring to him simply as 'painter', possibly thus differentiates him from familiars like Lely, Kneller and Wissing, for whom the word painter, with its artisan associations, would have been inappropriate and, as far as Susannah-Penelope is concerned, unnecessary.(2) 1 Autograph letter from Basil Long, serving with the army in France, to F W Stokes, as from c/o I.O,A.P.O. S.37, BEF; 20/5/17; endorsed by recipient Rec’d 22nd May Answered 12/7 /17F.WS. Dear Stokes, Yours of the 17th to hand. Excuse pencil as my pen is aeger. (1) I cannot remember whether I measured the 'Pocket book miniatures', but you can take it that I did if any of the Catalogue sizes differ from the Inventory sizes. [Memo. Today I have actual measts of 456-'92, EWS.22/5/17] (2) The set was reframed before I joined the Museum staff on May 8 1906; or possibly the frame was actually being made at that moment. (3) None of the Pocketbook mins. was retouched since 8/5/1906. (4) I do not think the flaking of Wignal is recent. I seem to remember it. But this sort of thing shows how important it is to record the condition of all ptgs. objects. I hope that as occasion permits you are proceeding with the record I instituted. [Yes: FWS] Have you looked at * photos ofWignal to see if he was flaking when they were taken? [*The photo shows just as much flaking and in the same places. EWS.J Anyhow, the blackening is not serious - it can be corrected just as well a year or more hence as now, so I think it had better continue at least until my next visit. Ditto the flaking, about which I shd.like a reply to the query above. I hope you aren't ungoldbeatering any of the mins. Yours sincerely B.S. Long PS. I hope you are not definitely assuming that the mins are by Rosse. PS. PI. tell Mr Kennedy I think it is time Turner's East Cows [sic] Castle was looked at. It requires very careful handling: no jarring. 2 I am grateful to Mary Edmond, personal communication, for the information on Mr Wignall."
